messages.text: What is the best way to type function argument that should be a vector of integers? AbstractVector{Integer} is my first guess but will this allow vectors of mixed integer sizes? Are there performance implications in doing so?

text.text: What is the best way to type function argument that should be a vector of integers? AbstractVector{Integer} is my first guess but will this allow vectors of mixed integer sizes? Are there performance implications in doing so?

messages.text: I do f(x::T) where T <: AbstractVector{T2} where T2<:Integer

text.text: I do f(x::T) where T <: AbstractVector{T2} where T2<:Integer

messages.text: The performance degradation comes with the type of the input, if it's a normal Vector{Int64}, it would be fine

text.text: The performance degradation comes with the type of the input, if it's a normal Vector{Int64}, it would be fine

messages.text: If you start pass a vector of mixed elements, there is a performance cost because that vector cannot be stored efficiently in memory

text.text: If you start pass a vector of mixed elements, there is a performance cost because that vector cannot be stored efficiently in memory

messages.text: Can Julia code compile to C? What is this tool? <https://github.com/JuliaComputing/llvm-cbe>

text.text: Can Julia code compile to C? What is this tool? <https://github.com/JuliaComputing/llvm-cbe>

messages.text: Nope, Julia compiles to native code, not C.

elements.text: Nope, Julia compiles to native code, not C.

messages.text: Julia compiles to LLVM IR (intermediate representation), and thereafter LLVM does the heavy lifting

text.text: Julia compiles to LLVM IR (intermediate representation), and thereafter LLVM does the heavy lifting

messages.text: if LLVM can compile its intermediate representation to C, then Julia can be compiled to C

text.text: if LLVM can compile its intermediate representation to C, then Julia can be compiled to C

attachments.text: You could potentially use Casette.jl to store the stacktrace every time a particular method is called. Apart from this, I do not think any such functionality exists.

messages.text: You could do  ``` julia> using OffsetArrays  julia> selectarray = OffsetVector([:a, :b, :c], -1:1) 3-element OffsetArray(::Vector{Symbol}, -1:1) with eltype Symbol with indices -1:1:  :a  :b  :c  julia> (⋚)(x, y) = x == y ? 0 : x < y ? -1 : 1 ⋚ (generic function with 1 method)  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 2] :a  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 1] :b  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ -1] :c ``` where `⋚` is typed `\lesseqgtr` and then hit the tab key.

text.text:
You could do 
```
julia> using OffsetArrays

julia> selectarray = OffsetVector([:a, :b, :c], -1:1)
3-element OffsetArray(::Vector{Symbol}, -1:1) with eltype Symbol with indices -1:1:
 :a
 :b
 :c

julia> (⋚)(x, y) = x == y ? 0 : x < y ? -1 : 1
⋚ (generic function with 1 method)

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 2]
:a

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 1]
:b

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ -1]
:c
```
where `⋚` is typed `\lesseqgtr` and then hit the tab key.

messages.text: Julia has a lot of great Unicode support. If you’re writing user facing code, it’s good to support an interface that does not explicitly require using Unicode (so at least provide ASCII fallback) because there will always be someone with a backwards system that can’t render it right

text.text: Julia has a lot of great Unicode support. If you’re writing user facing code, it’s good to support an interface that does not explicitly require using Unicode (so at least provide ASCII fallback) because there will always be someone with a backwards system that can’t render it right

messages.text: But generally, if you find that using Unicode helps you write code you like, use it.

text.text: But generally, if you find that using Unicode helps you write code you like, use it.

messages.text: hi everyone. i've been trying to reproduce a vector field plot example on julia 1.5.3 (from the answer here: <https://stackoverflow.com/a/52362537/4194280>), but `quiver()` raises an error about the dimensions of y. has something changed in Plots regarding the expansion of input data since this answer was posted? (I know there are other working methods to make this plot, but I'm curious why this example doesn't work anymore)

attachments.title: How can I plot vector field on Julia?
attachments.text: I'm new on Julia and I've tried to make the code of following post How to plot a vector field in Julia?, but, didn't work, so, I would like to know if it's possible to plot with the package "Plots"...
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: How can I plot vector field on Julia?

text.text: hi everyone. i've been trying to reproduce a vector field plot example on julia 1.5.3 (from the answer here: <https://stackoverflow.com/a/52362537/4194280>), but `quiver()` raises an error about the dimensions of y. has something changed in Plots regarding the expansion of input data since this answer was posted? (I know there are other working methods to make this plot, but I'm curious why this example doesn't work anymore)
